post: The printed word still matters. Through a partnership with TEAM Concept Printing and the Bill of Rights Institute, Komori America was proud to support the production of 10,000 pocket-sized Bill of Rights booklets for students across 100 Chicagoland schools. This project highlights the role print continues to play in education, civic understanding, and community engagement, and the power of collaboration across our industry. 📽️ Watch the video to see how print, partnership, and purpose come together.  https://bit.ly/4abH4c8  #PrintMatters  #Community  #CivicEducation  #Komori  #Partnership  #Education

Black History Month brings tough, vital questions about freedom and citizenship to the forefront of the nations mind. Put the Constitution on students desks to help them grapple with these important issues: $10 = 10 Pocket Constitutions. Support a local teacher today:  https://bit.ly/40EsBAg  #CivicsChampion  #BlackHistoryMonth  #CivicEducation  #Constitution

Were collecting teacher-tested A250 lesson moments to spotlight nationwide. Contribute one 50-word story, enter the weekly Civic Star Challenge drawing for up to $10,000, and inspire others to teach this national milestone well. Share this with your department:  https://bit.ly/463KXxf  #CivicStarChallenge  #America250  #CivicEducation  #TeacherCommunity

Do you know a student making an impact in your community? Students 13-19 can submit by May 3 for up to $10,000.  https://bit.ly/3EVuQY2  #MyImpactChallenge  #StudentLeadership  #ServiceLearning  #CivicEducation

DMTA helps students practice a rare skill: disagreeing without disrespect. Through structured debate with U. K. peers, students learn to listen closely, use evidence, and respond with clarity. Whats one norm you want to see more of in civic dialogue? 🔗  https://bit.ly/4aWAHd8  #DebatingMatters  #DMTA  #CivicEducation  #CriticalThinking

Katie Schneringers reflection from NCSS is the kind of teacher voice that sticks with you. As the 2025 Gary Colletti Scholarship recipient, Katie writes about something many educators rarely get mid-year: a genuine sense of renewal. From learning alongside social studies teachers nationwide, to quietly walking Washington, D. C. with no agenda beyond curiosity,  her piece captures what happens when teachers are supported, trusted, and given space to remember why this work matters. If you teach history or civics, this is worth a few minutes of your time:  https://bit.ly/4kIH2vN  #SocialStudies  #CivicEducation  #TeacherDevelopment  #ProfessionalLearning

Black History Month is a good moment to put primary sources in students hands. Mississippis 1861 Declaration of Secession states its cause plainly: slavery. Use this short Primary Source Essentials video to ground discussion in evidence, then ask: what claim is Mississippi making about the Union?  https://bit.ly/4kC8U4K  #PrimarySources  #CivicEducation  #AmericanHistory  #BlackHistoryMonth

That moment when students got it, when a debate shifted, a primary source clicked, a hard question landed. We want to hear about your A250 classroom moment in 50 words and enter the weekly Civic Star Challenge drawing for up to $10,000.  https://bit.ly/463KXxf  #CivicStarChallenge  #CivicEducation  #America250  #Teaching

Presidents Day classroom prompt: Where does presidential power come from, and where does it stop? Use these short, ready-to-use resources to build constitutional thinking:  https://bit.ly/3M5Fkba  #PresidentsDay  #CivicEducation  #Constitution  #Teaching
